Dr. Gerald P. Burns, president
of the Independent College Funds
of America, Inc., has been named
vice president for development of
the Johns Hopkins Hospital and
the Johns Hopkins University and
will be responsible for the fund
raising activities of both institutions.
The announcement was made
jointly by Dr. Russell A. Nelson,
president of the Hospital, and Dr.
Lincoln Gordon, president of the
University. Dr. Burns will also become president of the Johns Hopkins institutions. University Trustee M. Jenkins Cromwell, who is
now president, will become Chairman of the Board.

"Youth will make this one of the most
popular films ever produced. It will
quickly rank with that small number
of totally contemporary films that include The Beatles flicks, 'Morgan,'
'Blow Up' and a very few others.
"Dylan expresses something very,very
important about the New Youth. Our
sons and daughters are beyond our
command, and Dylan offers us clues
as to why.
"It is the most effective presentation
of the reality of contemporary youth
attitudes that I have ever seen. It is
also one of the best, if not the very
best, portrait of a performing artist
to be shown publicly.
"It ought to be seen dozens of times!"

oIk President's Assistant,
In Join Carnegie Group
Ronald A. Wolk, Special Assistto the President and Coordinator
of Planning of the Johns Hopkins
University has been named as
Assistant Director of the Carnegie
Commission on the Future of
Higher Educations.
The Commission, chaired and
directed by Clark Kerr, was created last January by the Carnegie
Foundation for the advancement
of Teaching. Its aim is to make a
comprehensive study of all the
phases of higher education in this
country and the complex elements
of society which affect higher
education.
Mr. Wolk has been at Hopkins
since 1958. In 1963 he was named
Special Assistant to Hopkins' President Milton S. Eisenhower. Two
years later he was elected Vice
President of the Johns Hopkins
Fund. This organization, presently
directed by Dr. Gerald Burns, controls the process of fund-raising
for the University. Mr. Wolk was
likewise appointed Coordinator of
University Planning.
For many years, Mr. Wolk has
been an active participant within
his field. He was, for example, director and secretary of Editorial
Projects for Education, and publisher of The Chronicle of Higher
Education,a bi-weekly newspaper.
He has also participated in the
American Association of Education and the American College
Public Relations Associations.

HOMEWOOD,BALTIMORE,DECEMBER 1, 1967

NEWS-LETTER

"What doesIBM offer a
Ph.D?I'd say diversity.But
judge for yourself when
they're here Dec.12th'
"I think IBM's worth listening to because the advantages
that attracted me are even stronger today.(This is Gary
Kozak,Ph.D. in Analytical-Physical Chemistry,an IBM
Development Chemist and Project Manager.)
"At IBM you're constantly working with people doing
advanced work in many different fields. That's a great asset
to any scientist because today's problems are often
interdisciplinary. You can't solve them with one kind of
background. You need inputs from three or four different
kinds of people.
"A good example is the solid logic technology used in
building the IBM System/360. The EE tells you how many
conductors you'll have, where they go,and what should be
at the terminals. An ME designs fixturing and automatic
processes. A Polymer Chemist formulates insulators
and says how they should be used. The Metallurgist
specifies alloy compositions. The Physicist decides how to
optimize a process for producing transistors and diodes.
And all these people have to talk with each other and
help each other.
"It's a stimulating environment,and it keeps you technologically sharp. Of course, to do all this interfacing with
other disciplines, you need a free and informal atmosphere,
and IBM has it. It's a good place for a scientist to work."
There's more to the IBM story than Gary has mentioned.
You can get all the facts when we interview Ph.D.'s on
campus. Make an appointment at your placement office,
even if you're headed for military service.
Or if you can't make a campus interview,send an outline
of your interests and educational background to
Mr. L. H.Covert,IBM,Armonk,
L-7 L
N.Y. 10504. We're an equal
opportunity employer.

Mr. Lyon Rogers
Director, Placement Center
The Johns Hopkins University
Dear Sir:
The Dow Chemical Company will be interviewing students for
permanent and summer employment on cwnpus December 4 and 5.
Dow Chemical is engaged in the production of napalm, a cruel and
inhunian instrument of war. The napalm made by Dow is used by the
American armed forces in their aggression against the people of
Vietnam.
We feel that the university has a duty to make a moraljudgement
on recwitment and that the university community as a whole, and
not the placement centre, should decide whether these recruiters are
to be allowed on campus. We demand the cancellation of the visit of
the Dow recruiters and challenge you to a public debate on the issue
of on-campus recruiting.
If no reply to this letter is received by noon Wednesday we will
feel justified in taking direct action in this matter.
Respectli141'

Republican Bias

Participatory Tyranny
Dow Chemical comes to this campus this week to recruit employees. The S.D.S. hopes to stop it. The result is that the whole moral
and political legitimacy of protest is destroyed, and that participatory democracy becomes tyranny.
Everyone, ideally, should have their say. And everyone should
have the freedom to choose. The Dow protestors have chosen to

Gone With the Wind
By KENNETH W. BOND
Republican National Chairman
Ray.Bliss was dead wrong when he
said the November 7 election results indicate "that the upsurge in
Republican strength which began
in 1966 is continuing." In reality,
it was a poor night for the GOP.
Republican gains in New Jersey,
Kentucky, and Hartford, Conn.
must be deemed truly insignificant when considering the Democrats swept control of nine major
U.S. cities: San Francisco, San Diego, Gary,Cleveland, Toledo, New
Haven, Boston, Philadelphia, and
Baltimore.
Here at home, the humiliation
stemming from the mayorality
race was not due to Arthur Sherwood's defeat, but because he was
literally creamed. It was a foregone conclusion to everyone that
Sherwood would lose; his campaign was admittedly an "exercise in futility." But to think that
he received less than 20 per cent
of the popular vote, coupled with
the fact that Democrats uniformly
defeated Republican (with one exception) in all six City Council
districts by overwhelming margins from 3-1 to 10-1, leads one to
ask the question: "What ever happened to the two-party system in
Baltimore?" If it ever was, it surely is dead now.
The factors which explain Baltimore's one party inanopoly begin
with the Democrats' commanding,
five to one voter registration margin. Baltimoreans are known to
happily cross lines if the other

party presents a better man. Thus,
Theodore McKeldin and Spiro
Agnew have carried the day in recent elections. A more significant
factor is evidenced by the continuous emmigration of the usually
Republican middle and high income families, leaving the city
limits inhabited by low-income
persons and minority groups - who
remain hypnotized by the New
Deal era and are, therefore, loyally
Democratic.
Most important, one must consider the campaign itself. Political
theory has it that the best way to
upset a one-party monopoly is for
the out-party to sponsor extremely
attractive candidates. Again, McKeldin and Agnew are prime examples. In many ways Sherwood
could have been attractive to the
voters, but in fact he was not.
First,Sherwood received negligible
support from his own party. No
one wants to back a loser; thus,
there were no finances for a dynamic publicity campaign. In addition, there was no campaign organization, no volunteer corp ringing doorbells, no active "youth
for Sherwood."
Second, there was Sherwood
himself: a nice guy, and all that,
but hardly the "John Lindsay of
Baltimore". He failed to motivate
and inspire his partisans the way
Agnew did in 1966. His public
impression was many times that of
frustrated and confused man not
sure at all of what he was supposed
to be doing. Thus, as the results
show, he didn't instill much coot -

dence in the voters.Yet, in priyate.
Sherwood was no coward He
stood up against the war, accosted
the Great Society for lack of federal revenues to rebuild his city,
and deplored the corruption embedded in his opposition.
Finally, there was Tommy
D'Alesandro III - - Baltimore's
Mayor-elect. He pocketed the
monopoly on everything: the magnetic name, billboards, bus signs,
T.V. - radio advertisement ("The
Answer is D'Alesandro
"), and
the votes: five of his to every one
of Sherwood's. He couldn't lose
short of a national catastrophy.
Thus, he aired no issues, presented
no alternatives, and made no rational appeals. He didn't have to;
he won the mayorship in the Democratic primary.
The tragedy of this election is
not that the Republicans ought to
have won. D'Alesandro probably
won't do anything so terrible as
might have required Sherwood to
save Baltimoreans from it. The
tragedy is that there is no longer a
healthy two-party system. D'Alesandro is accountable only to his
party, not to Baltimore citizens.
Since there is no loyal opposition
to check his administration,
D'Alesandro is free to govern as he
pleases. We can only hope that he
will choose to do so in an efficient and responsible in
Meanwhile, the Republican party
has been wiped out of Baltimore;
it is gone with the wind, When, or,
if, a viable GOP will return to challenge the city's inner machine is
anybody's guest.

Golden Age Celebrated at Walters

•
I.

By BILL SAKOWICH
Walters Art Gallery has seemingly developed into the sort of
establishment which creates interest only for the member of the
Baltimore Chamber of Commerce
who will mention it in a brochure
for prospective residents, to prove
that the city of monuments is a
culturally alive metropolis.
Having its nativity from the
wealthy Walters' private collection,
the museum is based in what used
to be the old family homestead.
Through the museum's needs,however, chez Walters has become a
curious conjugation of the Baroque and the Modern. Previously,
to set the tone for the ancient and
Renaissance works, the museum,
had kept its setting appropriate
for its ennumerable esoteric displays.
Avant Garde Jigsaw
Yet a strange thing is happening to the gallery today. It is desperately attempting to change its
image from a stodgy attic to a
genuine museum and art gallery
where Albert Common can browse
through and soak up some crudi-

ii

•••

tion for his culturally deprived
soul. For example, one may see a
rather stunning enamel from
France displayed in a neo-modern
church setting that looks strangely
like a Hutzler's Christmas display,
or purchase a jugsaw puzzle of
"Alexander the Great Enthroned
at Persepholis" by Nizami, or
Christmas Cards with Renaissance
paintings on the front.
Artistic Crop Rotation
One can definitely become frustrated working in an establishment
with so much potential that lies
fallow. It can be said without
question that the Walters' Art gal-

lery is the best
museum in the
city, and one of
best of its kind in
the nation. It houses many originals, from Raphael to El Greco,
0has a striking collection of French
Enamels, and an
extensive display
of Ancient Greek
Egyptian
and
sculpture. On display in the museum is a jewelled
marten's head that is a rare example of a fashionable artistic vogue
which appeared in Europe in the
Fifteenth and sixteenth centuries.
What makes the situation even
more frustrating is the fact that
there is not enough room in the
museum to display the entire collection at one time, and so various
exhibits must be rotated from the
halls to the basement.
Haven for Students
The museum is a haven for all
art students who wish to supplement their education, and for the
layman to become aware of the
artistic heritage of the ages; a heritage that is reincarnate on canvas.
Walters also presents concerts
featuring Peabody ensembles, at
which the audience is at liberty to
promenade about the premises to
enrich the appreciation of the
music.
Attendance Poor
But on the main, attendance at
these concerts is poor. The Gallery goes unnoticed or ignored by
a greater part of the city. The
Gallery is left to those few of the
upper class who wish to appreciate the "finer things in life", unruly, chattering children who are
thankful to escape the boredom of
the classroom, or to the dull borgeosie who wish to escape the
stillness of a Sunday afternoon.
The rest of the city is content to
worship at the tabernacle on Thirty-third street, or pick up their
culture packaged at a local cinema
or discotheque.

Yet Walters still waits patiently
on Charles Street for those interested with its cycle of exhibits and
unattended Peabody Concerts. The
paint on the portrait of the found*

er, William Walters, may be cracking around the forehead, but the
gallery is secure in the knowledge
that the painting will be eventually
restored.

FOOTBALL FOR SHUT-INS
At next Saturday's football game while you are sitting
in your choice student's seat behind the end zone, won't
you pause and give a thought to football's greatest and,
alas, most neglected name? I refer, of course, to Champert
Sigafoos.
Champert Sigafoos (1714-1928) started life humbly on
a farm near Thud, Kansas. His mother and father, both
named Walter, were bean-gleaners, and Champert became
a bean-gleaner too. But he tired of the work and went to
Montana where he got a job with a logging firm. Here the
erstwhile bean-gleaner worked as a stump-thumper. After
a month he went to North Dakota where he tended the
furnace in a granary (wheat-heater). Then he drifted to
Texas where he tidied up oil fields (pipe-wiper). Then to
ArLona where he strung dried fruit (fig-rigger). Then
to Kentucky where he fed horses at a breeding farm (oattoter). Then to Long Island where he dressed poultry
(duck-plucker). Then to Alaska where he drove a delivery
van for a bakery (bread-sledder). Then to Minnesota
where he cut up frozen lakes (ice-slicer). Then to Nevada
where he determined the odds in a gambling house (dicepricer). Then to Milwaukee where he pasted camera
lenses together (Zeiss-splicer).
Finally he went to Omaha where he got a job in a tannery, beating pig hides until they were soft and supple
(hog-flogger). Here occurred the event that changed not
only Champert's life, but all of ours.
Next door to Champert's hog-floggery was a mooring
mast for dirigibles. In flew a dirigible one day, piloted by
a girl named Graffa von Zeppelin. Champert watched
Graffa descend from the dirigible, and his heart turned
over, and he knew love. Though Graffa's beauty was not
quite perfect—one of her legs was shorter than the other
(blimp-gimper)—she was nonetheless ravishing, what
with her tawny hair and her eyes of Lake Louise blue and
her marvelously articulated haunches. Champert,smitten,
ran quickly back to the hog-fioggery to plan the wooing.
To begin with, naturally, he would give Graffa a present. This presented problems, for hog-flogging, as we all
know, is a signally underpaid profession. Still, thought
Champert, if he had no money, there were two things he
did have: ingenuity and pigskin.
So he selected several high grade pelts and stitched
them together and blew air into them and made for Graffa
a perfectly darling little replica of a dirigible. "She will
love this," said he confidently to himself and proceeded to
make ready to call on Graffa.
First, of course, he shaved with Personna Super Stainless Steel Blades. And wouldn't you? If you were looking
to impress a girl, if you wanted jowls as smooth as ivory,
dewlaps like damask,a chin strokable, cheeks fondlesome,
upper lip kissable, would you not use the blade that
whisks away whiskers quickly and slickly, tuglessly and
nicklessly, scratchlessly and matchlessly? Would you not,
in short, choose Personna, available both in Injector style
and double-edge style? Of course you would.

So Champert, his face a study in epidermal elegance,
rushed next door with his little pigskin dirigible. But
Graffa, alas, had run off, alas, with a bush pilot who specialized in dropping limes to scurvy-ridden Eskimo villages (fruit-chuter).
Champert, enraged, started kicking his little pigskin
blimp all over the place. And who should walk by just
then but Jim Thorpe, Knute Rockne, Walter Camp, and
Pete Rozelle!
They walked silently, heads down, four discouraged
men. For weeks they had been trying to invent football,
but they couldn't seem to find the right kind of ball. They
tried everything—hockey pucks, badminton birds, bowling
balls, quoits—but nothing worked. Now seeing Champert
kicking his pigskin spheroid, their faces lit up and as one
man they hollered "Eureka!" The rest is history.

halfback Weiss, who had been doing the team's heavy running all
year, who finally moved into the
limelight. Moving for 195 yeards on
30 carries including a 34 yard T.D.
run, a performance that made him
the Southern Division M.A.C.'s
top rusher for the year, the 5-11,
190 pound setback was the key
figure in Hopkins' hard-fought
13-6 win.
After somewhat dominating a
scoreless first half, the Jays went
ahead 7-0 on Weiss's jaunt following a fumble recovery. After another Hopkins thrust was stopped inside the Terror ten yard line, the
Westminster club took off on a
96 yard T.D. drive, but its twopoint conversion try failed. The
Homewood squad then iced the
win via a late scoring march capped by Mark Croft's short plunge.
The triumph left Hopkins atop the
Southern Division at 6-0; Western
Maryland and F&M were next at
3-2.

Some people get experience
in a job.
Other people get older.
There's a big difference. And
it all depends on where you
work, and with whom you
work. You can start some
place that has all the proper
systems engineering credentials — significant contracts,
modern physical plant, and
the usual fringe benefits —
and find yourself a couple of
years later, just a couple of
years behind.
Or, you can come to a place
like MITRE and get experience. And grow. We have the
credentials, of course.(We
happen to think they're the
best.) But we have something
more. An attitude. We want
you to get the best systems
experience in the business.
We want to share what we

The quicker you grasp things,

ball effort for eight seniors, a
group whose efforts Sotir praised.
They include co-captains Perlmutter and Ferrazzano, safety and sub
quarterback Mike Shaw("the hardest hitter for his size we've got"),
Thomas, Komocki("who hung in
on defense despite two knee injuries"), Bachur ("whose two field
goals provided the margin in the
F&M game"), Walt Sienkiewicz
("who improved steadily all
year"),and Scott Black.
Weiss and Cowan,with, respectively, 639 yards on 114 carries
and 463 yards on 57 tries for 5.6
and 8.1 means, provided the bulk
of the Jay ground totals. Also
contributing were Will Scroggs
(17-83-4.9), Jeff Sienkiewica (3081-2.7), and Croft (23-71-3.1).
Quarterback Jim Feely (fourth in
Southern Division in passing) completed 69 of 108 passes for 1264
yards (a school record) with five
interceptions and twelve touchdowns, (another record). Cowan
(3-3 for 78 yards and a T.D.),

for 458 and six scores, and Sienkiewicz eight for 128 yards. Cowan's punting average, kickoff return yardage (354), kickoff return touchdowns (two) total

By MIKE PHILLIPS
Triumphant over arch-rival Western Maryland in its season finale,
the varsity football team - via possibly the most spectacular oneyear grid reversal in Hopkins grid
history - has finished the 1967
campaign with a 6-1 mark, the
Southern Division Middle Atlantic Converence title, numerous
new school records, and an abundance of individual honors.
In moving up from 1966's
0-6-2 card, the team broke a sixyear string of losing season (8-34-5
cumulatively during that stretch);
and came up with the best Homewood grid performance since the
glory days of 1959-60, when Hopkins squads coached by Wilson
Fewster finished 7-1 and 5-2-1.
Probable causes of the rise are
numerous.
First among the group's more
tangible assets as it entered the
1967 campaign was its returning
crew of twelve lettermen, seven
concentrated in the offensive line
and all bloodied and hardened by
1966's misfortunes. Of further
importance was the equally-sized
upcoming sophomore group - most
importantly, defensive tackles Jim
Lotto and Ken Brown, halfback
Paul Weiss, offensive linemen Bill
Ncrsesian and Mike Wilbanks, and
linebacker-end Wil Rholfing —
from 1966's undefeated freshman
group.
Newcomers Shine
More surprising -- and certainly
vital to Coach Alex Sotir's planned
two-platoon system — were the
performances of a group of playrs absent for varying lengths of
time from the grid wars. Chief
imong these were sometime-place
kicker Wes Bachur, defensive linemen Wit Holden and Brian Turner,
defensive backs Dave Thomas and
Charlie Coker (all of whom had
never played football at Hopkins),
and defensive end Dave Komocki.
Sotir was especially pleased by the
jobs done by Coker and Thomas,
stating that this twosome, despite
inexperience, "were never beaten
deep all year."
Also on the list of extended
layoffs, but perhaps deserving of

"Brandy" Picked
As New Trainer
Mr. LeRoy Brandimore, an exNaval Corpsman has recently been
appointed by the Athletic Department as athletic trainer. Ile will
replace the late Jimmy Benson
who served for 41 years.
A Naval veteran of twenty-three
years Mr. Brandimore will assume
his duties on December 1 . Serving
as a Hospital Corpsman,First Class,
he has made two tours 01 duty as
assistant trainer at the Naval Acadmy during a five- year period.
Mr. Brandimore received extensive medical and administration
experience during his Naval service,
which has included some action in
the vicinity of Vietnam. The new
trainer is forty-two years of age
and he resided in Arnold. Maryland.
Marshall Turner commented
that he was pleased that Mr.
Brandmoie was able to come to
the Hopkins. Turner stated that
Brandimore would definitely "be
an asset" to the athletic staff.

JOE COWAN
his own categorization, is wingback Joe Cowan, a recent Honorable Mention Little All-America
choice in his first year of football
since 1964. The 5-10, 175 pound
junior, probably Hopkins' top offensive threat all year, played a
vital role in at least four of the
Jays' six wins, and in the process
became a Baltimore Sun First
Team All-Maryland pick. He led
the Southern Division of the Middle Atlantic Conference in scoring
(77 points, 89 for the season) and
punting (41.8 yards per kick),
while finishing fourth in that league in rushing and eighth in pass
receiving.
Few Injuries
Sotir, for his part, was more
apt to stress the role that luck
played in 1967 Jay grid successes.
"We were very fortunate injurywise this season," he related;"since
most of our key players went the
season unhurt. It's a good thing
they did," the varsity mentor continued, "because there wasn't too
much depth behind them."
"We were also lucky to get off
to a good start, and thus gain momentum we never lost. Our opening game with Franklin and Marshall (a 19-14 win in the final
minutes) could easily have been
lost, and if it had the whole season might have been different."
"The team's attitude and motivation, though," he went on,

By BOB HYAMS
The Hopkins Soccer team gained its first winning season since
1964 by posting an overall record
of 6-5 this year.
The Jays lost their final match
on Saturday, November 25 to
Dickinson College by a score of
2-1. It completed a season which
was highlighted by our beating
Drexel for the first time in 20
years.
The booters finished on a strong
note, winning three out of their
opponents' total of 19. They outshot their opponents 235-166. A
team is supposed to score on the
average of one goal for every 10
shots.
In the losing Dickinson game,
the Jays scored in the first 20 seconds on a toss-in from out of
bounds. Kit Battenfeld headed the
ball to Randy Miller who collected the goal. Also assisting on the
play was Art Guerin.
Dickinson tied the score at 1-1,
three minutes later. There was no
further scoring until the final four
minutes in the last quarter when a
corner kick resulted in a scramble
in front of the Jay goal, culminating in the winning Dickinson
score. Dickinson completed its season with an 8-2-2 record.
Next year the team loses four
starters via graduation: Wes Bachur, Kit Battenfeld, Peter Martindale, and John Sarney. There will
be 13 returning lettermen with
some good freshmen moving up to
the varsity. Coach Barrette felt
that the team would be stronger
next year with the major scoring
punch coming from Dave Roberts,
Ken Niman and Bernie Wenker.
Coach Barrette was pleased with
the fine year-round effort. Pete
Martindale, who took over the
goalie position from Mike Avery
(All-Conference last year) only
gave up 11 goals in eight games.
Also deserving Kudos are sophomores Randy Miller and Rich Tobey and co-captains Wes Bachur
and John Sarney.

Attempting to reassert itself
after last year's disappointments,
the varsity basketball team — virtually intact from 1966-67 but
somewhat altered in style and
with prospects best described as
ambiguous — will open its current
campaign by hosting Haverford
tomorrow at 8:30 p.m.
Head Coach Henry Ciccarone,
yet to field a winner in five tries
(the last Hopkins cage crew above
.500 played in the late 1940's),
rated Haverford as "just about our
weakest opponent this year" and
added — accurately enough — that
"If we don't beat them it could
mean a long season."

Ciccarone's moderate pessimism — a feeling shared by many
of the team's observers — would,
considering the return of six letterp.m and four starters, the presence of some good sophomore
prospects, and availibility of the
size much lacking last season, appear groundless; but awareness of
the course of the 1966-67 Jay
campaign and so-so pre-season
scrimmage performances justify
his concern.
Overconfidence
"After all of iast year's overconfidence (Hopkins, picked for
better things by most, finished
7-5 in the Southern Division of the
Middle Atlantic Conference and
8-9 overall), a little pessimism
around here won't hurt," opined
Ciccarone. "We didn't get very
many breaks a year ago, but that
was hardly the only reason we did
relatively poorly: too many peo-

ple thought too many games were
won before the season even started.
The team has got to play its games
one at a time."
The cagers' scrimmage performances have hardly been such as
to dispel the above forebodings.
In 95-86 and 74-65 wins over an
Alexandria (Va.) amateur team
and Southeastern University and
84-62, 80-75, and 75-49 losses to,
respectively, Howard University,
Baltimore Junior College,and Morgan State College (Hopkins scrimmaged Baltimore University Wednesday night), the Jays — have
looked effective only in spots,
although the latter three foes are
probably superior to most of the
opposition they will see this year.

Ronald A. Wolk, Special Assistto the President and Coordinator
of Planning of the Johns Hopkins
University has been named as

Commission on the Future of

comprehensive study of all the
phases of higher education in this

of society which affect higher
education.

Special Assistant to Hopkins' President Milton S. Eisenhower. Two

President of the Johns Hopkins

directed by Dr. Gerald Burns, controls the process of fund-raising

likewise appointed Coordinator of
University Planning.

Education,a bi-weekly newspaper.

American Association of Education and the American College
Public Relations Associations.

"What doesIBM offer a
Ph.D?I'd say diversity.But
judge for yourself when
they're here Dec.12th'
"I think IBM's worth listening to because the advantages
that attracted me are even stronger today.(This is Gary
Kozak,Ph.D. in Analytical-Physical Chemistry,an IBM
Development Chemist and Project Manager.)
"At IBM you're constantly working with people doing
advanced work in many different fields. That's a great asset
to any scientist because today's problems are often
interdisciplinary. You can't solve them with one kind of
background. You need inputs from three or four different
kinds of people.
"A good example is the solid logic technology used in
building the IBM System/360. The EE tells you how many
conductors you'll have, where they go,and what should be
at the terminals. An ME designs fixturing and automatic
processes. A Polymer Chemist formulates insulators
and says how they should be used. The Metallurgist
specifies alloy compositions. The Physicist decides how to
optimize a process for producing transistors and diodes.
And all these people have to talk with each other and
help each other.
"It's a stimulating environment,and it keeps you technologically sharp. Of course, to do all this interfacing with
other disciplines, you need a free and informal atmosphere,
and IBM has it. It's a good place for a scientist to work."
There's more to the IBM story than Gary has mentioned.
You can get all the facts when we interview Ph.D.'s on
campus. Make an appointment at your placement office,
even if you're headed for military service.
Or if you can't make a campus interview,send an outline
of your interests and educational background to
Mr. L. H.Covert,IBM,Armonk,

N.Y. 10504. We're an equal
opportunity employer.

Gone With the Wind
By KENNETH W. BOND
Republican National Chairman
Ray.Bliss was dead wrong when he
said the November 7 election results indicate "that the upsurge in
Republican strength which began
in 1966 is continuing." In reality,
it was a poor night for the GOP.
Republican gains in New Jersey,
Kentucky, and Hartford, Conn.
must be deemed truly insignificant when considering the Democrats swept control of nine major
U.S. cities: San Francisco, San Diego, Gary,Cleveland, Toledo, New
Haven, Boston, Philadelphia, and
Baltimore.
Here at home, the humiliation
stemming from the mayorality
race was not due to Arthur Sherwood's defeat, but because he was
literally creamed. It was a foregone conclusion to everyone that
Sherwood would lose; his campaign was admittedly an "exercise in futility." But to think that
he received less than 20 per cent
of the popular vote, coupled with
the fact that Democrats uniformly
defeated Republican (with one exception) in all six City Council
districts by overwhelming margins from 3-1 to 10-1, leads one to
ask the question: "What ever happened to the two-party system in
Baltimore?" If it ever was, it surely is dead now.
The factors which explain Baltimore's one party inanopoly begin
with the Democrats' commanding,
five to one voter registration margin. Baltimoreans are known to
happily cross lines if the other

party presents a better man. Thus,
Theodore McKeldin and Spiro
Agnew have carried the day in recent elections. A more significant
factor is evidenced by the continuous emmigration of the usually
Republican middle and high income families, leaving the city
limits inhabited by low-income
persons and minority groups - who
remain hypnotized by the New
Deal era and are, therefore, loyally
Democratic.
Most important, one must consider the campaign itself. Political
theory has it that the best way to
upset a one-party monopoly is for
the out-party to sponsor extremely
attractive candidates. Again, McKeldin and Agnew are prime examples. In many ways Sherwood
could have been attractive to the
voters, but in fact he was not.
First,Sherwood received negligible
support from his own party. No
one wants to back a loser; thus,
there were no finances for a dynamic publicity campaign. In addition, there was no campaign organization, no volunteer corp ringing doorbells, no active "youth
for Sherwood."
Second, there was Sherwood
himself: a nice guy, and all that,
but hardly the "John Lindsay of
Baltimore". He failed to motivate
and inspire his partisans the way
Agnew did in 1966. His public
impression was many times that of
frustrated and confused man not
sure at all of what he was supposed
to be doing. Thus, as the results
show, he didn't instill much coot -

dence in the voters.Yet, in priyate.
Sherwood was no coward He
stood up against the war, accosted
the Great Society for lack of federal revenues to rebuild his city,
and deplored the corruption embedded in his opposition.
Finally, there was Tommy
D'Alesandro III - - Baltimore's
Mayor-elect. He pocketed the
monopoly on everything: the magnetic name, billboards, bus signs,
T.V. - radio advertisement ("The
Answer is D'Alesandro
"), and
the votes: five of his to every one
of Sherwood's. He couldn't lose
short of a national catastrophy.
Thus, he aired no issues, presented
no alternatives, and made no rational appeals. He didn't have to;
he won the mayorship in the Democratic primary.
The tragedy of this election is
not that the Republicans ought to
have won. D'Alesandro probably
won't do anything so terrible as
might have required Sherwood to
save Baltimoreans from it. The
tragedy is that there is no longer a
healthy two-party system. D'Alesandro is accountable only to his
party, not to Baltimore citizens.
Since there is no loyal opposition
to check his administration,
D'Alesandro is free to govern as he
pleases. We can only hope that he
will choose to do so in an efficient and responsible in
Meanwhile, the Republican party
has been wiped out of Baltimore;
it is gone with the wind, When, or,
if, a viable GOP will return to challenge the city's inner machine is
anybody's guest.

NEWS-LETTER

Golden Age Celebrated at Walters

•
I.

By BILL SAKOWICH
Walters Art Gallery has seemingly developed into the sort of
establishment which creates interest only for the member of the
Baltimore Chamber of Commerce
who will mention it in a brochure
for prospective residents, to prove
that the city of monuments is a
culturally alive metropolis.
Having its nativity from the
wealthy Walters' private collection,
the museum is based in what used
to be the old family homestead.
Through the museum's needs,however, chez Walters has become a
curious conjugation of the Baroque and the Modern. Previously,
to set the tone for the ancient and
Renaissance works, the museum,
had kept its setting appropriate
for its ennumerable esoteric displays.
Avant Garde Jigsaw
Yet a strange thing is happening to the gallery today. It is desperately attempting to change its
image from a stodgy attic to a
genuine museum and art gallery
where Albert Common can browse
through and soak up some crudi-

ii

•••

tion for his culturally deprived
soul. For example, one may see a
rather stunning enamel from
France displayed in a neo-modern
church setting that looks strangely
like a Hutzler's Christmas display,
or purchase a jugsaw puzzle of
"Alexander the Great Enthroned
at Persepholis" by Nizami, or
Christmas Cards with Renaissance
paintings on the front.
Artistic Crop Rotation
One can definitely become frustrated working in an establishment
with so much potential that lies
fallow. It can be said without
question that the Walters' Art gal-

lery is the best
museum in the
city, and one of
best of its kind in
the nation. It houses many originals, from Raphael to El Greco,
0has a striking collection of French
Enamels, and an
extensive display
of Ancient Greek
Egyptian
and
sculpture. On display in the museum is a jewelled
marten's head that is a rare example of a fashionable artistic vogue
which appeared in Europe in the
Fifteenth and sixteenth centuries.
What makes the situation even
more frustrating is the fact that
there is not enough room in the
museum to display the entire collection at one time, and so various
exhibits must be rotated from the
halls to the basement.
Haven for Students
The museum is a haven for all
art students who wish to supplement their education, and for the
layman to become aware of the
artistic heritage of the ages; a heritage that is reincarnate on canvas.
Walters also presents concerts
featuring Peabody ensembles, at
which the audience is at liberty to
promenade about the premises to
enrich the appreciation of the
music.
Attendance Poor
But on the main, attendance at
these concerts is poor. The Gallery goes unnoticed or ignored by
a greater part of the city. The
Gallery is left to those few of the
upper class who wish to appreciate the "finer things in life", unruly, chattering children who are
thankful to escape the boredom of
the classroom, or to the dull borgeosie who wish to escape the
stillness of a Sunday afternoon.
The rest of the city is content to
worship at the tabernacle on Thirty-third street, or pick up their
culture packaged at a local cinema
or discotheque.

Yet Walters still waits patiently
on Charles Street for those interested with its cycle of exhibits and
unattended Peabody Concerts. The
paint on the portrait of the found*

er, William Walters, may be cracking around the forehead, but the
gallery is secure in the knowledge

FOOTBALL FOR SHUT-INS
At next Saturday's football game while you are sitting
in your choice student's seat behind the end zone, won't
you pause and give a thought to football's greatest and,
alas, most neglected name? I refer, of course, to Champert
Sigafoos.
Champert Sigafoos (1714-1928) started life humbly on
a farm near Thud, Kansas. His mother and father, both
named Walter, were bean-gleaners, and Champert became
a bean-gleaner too. But he tired of the work and went to
Montana where he got a job with a logging firm. Here the
erstwhile bean-gleaner worked as a stump-thumper. After
a month he went to North Dakota where he tended the
furnace in a granary (wheat-heater). Then he drifted to
Texas where he tidied up oil fields (pipe-wiper). Then to
ArLona where he strung dried fruit (fig-rigger). Then
to Kentucky where he fed horses at a breeding farm (oattoter). Then to Long Island where he dressed poultry
(duck-plucker). Then to Alaska where he drove a delivery
van for a bakery (bread-sledder). Then to Minnesota
where he cut up frozen lakes (ice-slicer). Then to Nevada
where he determined the odds in a gambling house (dicepricer). Then to Milwaukee where he pasted camera
lenses together (Zeiss-splicer).
Finally he went to Omaha where he got a job in a tannery, beating pig hides until they were soft and supple
(hog-flogger). Here occurred the event that changed not
only Champert's life, but all of ours.
Next door to Champert's hog-floggery was a mooring
mast for dirigibles. In flew a dirigible one day, piloted by
a girl named Graffa von Zeppelin. Champert watched
Graffa descend from the dirigible, and his heart turned
over, and he knew love. Though Graffa's beauty was not
quite perfect—one of her legs was shorter than the other
(blimp-gimper)—she was nonetheless ravishing, what
with her tawny hair and her eyes of Lake Louise blue and
her marvelously articulated haunches. Champert,smitten,
ran quickly back to the hog-fioggery to plan the wooing.
To begin with, naturally, he would give Graffa a present. This presented problems, for hog-flogging, as we all
know, is a signally underpaid profession. Still, thought
Champert, if he had no money, there were two things he
did have: ingenuity and pigskin.
So he selected several high grade pelts and stitched
them together and blew air into them and made for Graffa
a perfectly darling little replica of a dirigible. "She will
love this," said he confidently to himself and proceeded to
make ready to call on Graffa.
First, of course, he shaved with Personna Super Stainless Steel Blades. And wouldn't you? If you were looking
to impress a girl, if you wanted jowls as smooth as ivory,
dewlaps like damask,a chin strokable, cheeks fondlesome,
upper lip kissable, would you not use the blade that
whisks away whiskers quickly and slickly, tuglessly and
nicklessly, scratchlessly and matchlessly? Would you not,
in short, choose Personna, available both in Injector style
and double-edge style? Of course you would.

So Champert, his face a study in epidermal elegance,
rushed next door with his little pigskin dirigible. But
Graffa, alas, had run off, alas, with a bush pilot who specialized in dropping limes to scurvy-ridden Eskimo villages (fruit-chuter).
Champert, enraged, started kicking his little pigskin
blimp all over the place. And who should walk by just
then but Jim Thorpe, Knute Rockne, Walter Camp, and
Pete Rozelle!
They walked silently, heads down, four discouraged
men. For weeks they had been trying to invent football,
but they couldn't seem to find the right kind of ball. They
tried everything—hockey pucks, badminton birds, bowling
balls, quoits—but nothing worked. Now seeing Champert
kicking his pigskin spheroid, their faces lit up and as one
man they hollered "Eureka!" The rest is history.

By MIKE PHILLIPS
Triumphant over arch-rival Western Maryland in its season finale,
the varsity football team - via possibly the most spectacular oneyear grid reversal in Hopkins grid
history - has finished the 1967
campaign with a 6-1 mark, the
Southern Division Middle Atlantic Converence title, numerous
new school records, and an abundance of individual honors.
In moving up from 1966's
0-6-2 card, the team broke a sixyear string of losing season (8-34-5
cumulatively during that stretch);
and came up with the best Homewood grid performance since the
glory days of 1959-60, when Hopkins squads coached by Wilson
Fewster finished 7-1 and 5-2-1.
Probable causes of the rise are
numerous.
First among the group's more
tangible assets as it entered the
1967 campaign was its returning
crew of twelve lettermen, seven
concentrated in the offensive line
and all bloodied and hardened by
1966's misfortunes. Of further
importance was the equally-sized
upcoming sophomore group - most
importantly, defensive tackles Jim
Lotto and Ken Brown, halfback
Paul Weiss, offensive linemen Bill
Ncrsesian and Mike Wilbanks, and
linebacker-end Wil Rholfing —
from 1966's undefeated freshman
group.
Newcomers Shine
More surprising -- and certainly
vital to Coach Alex Sotir's planned
two-platoon system — were the
performances of a group of playrs absent for varying lengths of
time from the grid wars. Chief
imong these were sometime-place
kicker Wes Bachur, defensive linemen Wit Holden and Brian Turner,
defensive backs Dave Thomas and
Charlie Coker (all of whom had
never played football at Hopkins),
and defensive end Dave Komocki.
Sotir was especially pleased by the
jobs done by Coker and Thomas,
stating that this twosome, despite
inexperience, "were never beaten
deep all year."

layoffs, but perhaps deserving of

"Brandy" Picked
As New Trainer
Mr. LeRoy Brandimore, an exNaval Corpsman has recently been
appointed by the Athletic Department as athletic trainer. Ile will
replace the late Jimmy Benson
who served for 41 years.
A Naval veteran of twenty-three
years Mr. Brandimore will assume
his duties on December 1 . Serving
as a Hospital Corpsman,First Class,
he has made two tours 01 duty as
assistant trainer at the Naval Acadmy during a five- year period.
Mr. Brandimore received extensive medical and administration
experience during his Naval service,
which has included some action in
the vicinity of Vietnam. The new
trainer is forty-two years of age
and he resided in Arnold. Maryland.
Marshall Turner commented
that he was pleased that Mr.
Brandmoie was able to come to
the Hopkins. Turner stated that
Brandimore would definitely "be
an asset" to the athletic staff.

choice in his first year of football
since 1964. The 5-10, 175 pound

vital role in at least four of the

they did," the varsity mentor continued, "because there wasn't too
much depth behind them."
"We were also lucky to get off
to a good start, and thus gain momentum we never lost. Our opening game with Franklin and Marshall (a 19-14 win in the final
minutes) could easily have been
lost, and if it had the whole season might have been different."

By BOB HYAMS
The Hopkins Soccer team gained its first winning season since
1964 by posting an overall record
of 6-5 this year.
The Jays lost their final match
on Saturday, November 25 to
Dickinson College by a score of
2-1. It completed a season which
was highlighted by our beating
Drexel for the first time in 20
years.
The booters finished on a strong
note, winning three out of their
opponents' total of 19. They outshot their opponents 235-166. A
team is supposed to score on the
average of one goal for every 10
shots.
In the losing Dickinson game,
the Jays scored in the first 20 seconds on a toss-in from out of
bounds. Kit Battenfeld headed the
ball to Randy Miller who collected the goal. Also assisting on the
play was Art Guerin.
Dickinson tied the score at 1-1,
three minutes later. There was no
further scoring until the final four
minutes in the last quarter when a
corner kick resulted in a scramble
in front of the Jay goal, culminating in the winning Dickinson
score. Dickinson completed its season with an 8-2-2 record.
Next year the team loses four
starters via graduation: Wes Bachur, Kit Battenfeld, Peter Martindale, and John Sarney. There will
be 13 returning lettermen with
some good freshmen moving up to
the varsity. Coach Barrette felt
that the team would be stronger
next year with the major scoring
punch coming from Dave Roberts,
Ken Niman and Bernie Wenker.
Coach Barrette was pleased with
the fine year-round effort. Pete
Martindale, who took over the
goalie position from Mike Avery
(All-Conference last year) only
gave up 11 goals in eight games.
Also deserving Kudos are sophomores Randy Miller and Rich Tobey and co-captains Wes Bachur
and John Sarney.

Attempting to reassert itself
after last year's disappointments,
the varsity basketball team — virtually intact from 1966-67 but
somewhat altered in style and
with prospects best described as
ambiguous — will open its current
campaign by hosting Haverford
tomorrow at 8:30 p.m.
Head Coach Henry Ciccarone,
yet to field a winner in five tries
(the last Hopkins cage crew above
.500 played in the late 1940's),
rated Haverford as "just about our
weakest opponent this year" and
added — accurately enough — that
"If we don't beat them it could
mean a long season."

Ciccarone's moderate pessimism — a feeling shared by many
of the team's observers — would,
considering the return of six letterp.m and four starters, the presence of some good sophomore
prospects, and availibility of the
size much lacking last season, appear groundless; but awareness of
the course of the 1966-67 Jay
campaign and so-so pre-season
scrimmage performances justify
his concern.
Overconfidence
"After all of iast year's overconfidence (Hopkins, picked for
better things by most, finished
7-5 in the Southern Division of the
Middle Atlantic Conference and
8-9 overall), a little pessimism
around here won't hurt," opined
Ciccarone. "We didn't get very
many breaks a year ago, but that
was hardly the only reason we did
relatively poorly: too many peo-

ple thought too many games were
won before the season even started.
The team has got to play its games
one at a time."
The cagers' scrimmage performances have hardly been such as
to dispel the above forebodings.
In 95-86 and 74-65 wins over an
Alexandria (Va.) amateur team
and Southeastern University and
84-62, 80-75, and 75-49 losses to,
respectively, Howard University,
Baltimore Junior College,and Morgan State College (Hopkins scrimmaged Baltimore University Wednesday night), the Jays — have
looked effective only in spots,
although the latter three foes are
probably superior to most of the
opposition they will see this year.
